thread.title: Indigenous rugby sevens teams prepare for national competition
thread.title_full: Indigenous rugby sevens teams prepare for national competition

title: Indigenous rugby sevens teams prepare for national competition
text:
Map: Rockhampton 4700 
Two Queensland rugby union teams will be pitted against the rest of the country when they head to one of Australia's biggest Indigenous sevens tournaments. 
The CQ Black Magic Sevens [men's] team and women's team, the Highlanders, are the only teams from Queensland to take part in the Ella Sevens in Coffs Harbour this weekend. 
Both teams are predominantly made up of central Queensland players. 
Highlanders coach Nikki Muller said the pressure was on for players to impress with Australian Rugby Union (ARU) officials at the matches. 
"All of them are keen to one day hopefully represent their mob," she said. 
"We've actually got one young girl with us now who is formerly of Clermont. She has just been named in the Australia Rugby Union under-18s team Youth Commonwealth squad." 
It will be the fourth time the Highlanders have made it to the tournament and Muller said the team was hoping to better their previous performances. 
"We've been lucky enough to make three finals but we just haven't got over the line yet," she said. Promoting talents of regional rugby players 
CQ Black Magic Rugby Sevens team manager Jade Smith said the competition would help promote regional players on a national stage. 
He said there were more than 80 Indigenous rugby union players living in central Queensland. 
"[That] is a lot considering rugby league is the biggest sport in Australia and we're all pretty much raised to watch the State of Origin," Smith said. 
"There's no actual sevens competition here in central Queensland. 
"You have to travel to Brisbane or Sydney but all the boys have the talent up here and I guess this is the opportunity that we're trying to provide with Black Magic." 
Smith said at each tournament in which they competed, they promoted a different health message which had helped improve the team's well-being. 
"A lot of the boys [are into] smoking and drinking [but] having to train for a national Indigenous carnival, they've cut back, they've done their health checks," he said. 
"They're trying to better themselves because we're going to be playing on a national stage, in front of a national audience. 
"That's what we want to see our in community and in our Indigenous mob â€” that you don't have to be drinking all the time to have fun. 
"You can train well, look after yourself and still have the benefits of being with your mates." Women's rugby getting more attention since Olympics 
Muller said many female Indigenous players had relocated to Brisbane to further their sporting careers. 
"Unfortunately, there are more opportunities down in the city than there are out in the country, out in rural areas," she said. 
"We built the team [the Highlanders] because we wanted to give the girls out in the rural and country areas an opportunity to thrive in mainstream." 
Muller said the code had seen an influx of new players in recent years. External Link: Highlanders FB post 
"I think it's starting to get more interest after the Olympics and [because of] how well the women's program has developed over the last couple of years," she said. 
"They're world champions, they're gold medallists and now everybody is getting into that sport, especially young girls and women right across Australia." 
Muller said finding new recruits from regional centres was made easier by existing players. 
"We probably have a base of 55 [players who] actually notice girls back in their home towns and they get in touch," she said. 
"That's all it takes from our girls because we want them to identify other young girls in their own communities." 
Both teams say funding tournament trips was the biggest issue for them and Muller said this had meant she paid for the majority of all the costs herself, but the teams are hoping to secure sponsors. 
The competition will take place on Friday March 3 and Saturday March 4.
